title: How come Swain ult doesn't drain stealthed/enemies in bushes?
body:
If you don't have vision on an enemy champion whether they are stealthed or in a bush right next to him that he doesn't have vision in his ultimate won't do any drain damage. 

Easy to test this, have an Akali use W and stand in her shroud with an enemy Swain having ult active and standing in the shroud. 

Or have a Swain ult then walk into a bush he has no vision in.

Isn't this kind of inconsistent with other abilities, though? Like, for sure, this is a great reason to not have an ability target stealthed enemies, but when there are abilities like Morgana's ult, Katarina's ult, Kennen's W, etc. to name but a few examples of abilities that do target stealthed champions, having all of these abilities do one thing, and having one ability that does very similar things, with this one exception, isn't really clear to players. Hecarim's W leaves a particle effect and damages stealthed enemies, even when he's on the move, Camille's Hookshot gains extra range against stealthed champions, even if they're invisible, and Zombie Brand infamously had this issue where he'd start doing his zombie walk when near _any_ champion, including champions that were invisible to him. It should therefore not be a coding issue, since we have plenty of abilities in-game that can detect invisible enemies on the fly, plus Wav3Break mentioned that Swain's special case was intended.

Here's a fun one! I play Evelynn when I go jungle. After you hit level six and get your stealth passive your "sighted" indicator goes off even whenever a stealthed enemy is around, making you a real neat trinket with legs. {{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

Your point is fair and I also agree that consistency is important. In this particular case there's 1 main reason why I valued this interaction over consistency. The biggest difference between the spells you've named and Swain's ultimate is duration of effects. This to me was the crux of my decision making at the time. I wanted to carve out power budget in Swain's kit to maximize the duration of his ultimate in order to better reflect the experience of his old ult. I saw this mechanic as a minor design optimization that gave me valuable room in pursuing that goal. 

From an adjacent angle, the burden of play for the spells you've mentioned are also much higher since they resolve much faster, have shorter range, are un-castable when there are no valid enemies nearby and include mechanics like keeping in range for X time / marking enemies before hand. All of these aspects make them much more contextual than Swain's ultimate and it would feel like unnecessary counter play for them to also adhere to vision rules strictly. 

I think you can make a reasonable argument that the amount of power budget I'm actually buying for Swain's ult duration isn't worth the consistency/expectation cost, but at the time this was the rationale I had for it being a reasonable trade off. 

My personal taste is to preserve the power of vision control when possible. Another place on Swain I'd highlight is that his E doesn't reveal targets it roots (we are pretty inconsistent on this stuff as well) but his W is a semi-global reveal which offsets that. I felt dis-empowering the base-line functionality of E here actually created more synergy in his kit internally and made accessing his power feel more intentional.

> [{quoted}](name=Wav3Break,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=roxpMzNU,comment-id=000a00020004,timestamp=2018-07-14T03:04:45.450+0000)
> 
> I think you can make a reasonable argument that the amount of power budget I'm actually buying for Swain's ult duration isn't worth the consistency/expectation cost, but at the time this was the rationale I had for it being a reasonable trade off. 

I mean, at the end of the day it comes down to how much one values micro-optimizations over consistency, though at the same time I'm personally averse to making exceptions to a general rule for reasons that are not themselves exceptional. In this particular case, power budget is a vast, general thing that could be approached from a bunch of different ways, many of which would not incur a long-term cost such as a degradation to the game's consistency. While it was an honorable decision to try to preserve the old ult's duration, at this point I feel the focus has nonetheless shifted from the drain to the explosion at the end, so players have an incentive to shorten the duration as much as possible in most cases. In this respect, I feel removing this exception may not affect Swain or his power budget as drastically as had been anticipated.

On the subject of vision and stealth detection, though, I also very much agree that vision should be kept sparse, yet clearly impactful. In this respect, it may perhaps be better to flip the situation, and remove stealth detection from a whole bunch of abilities, instead of adding it on Swain. In general, vision still feels like largely unexplored territory on champion kits, and is also a hotbed of inconsistent behavior: some abilities reveal the area where they land, other don't, some will reveal enemies they hit, others just have an impact sound, and some give strictly no response to whether or not they hit out of vision. Almost every time, there is no explanation on the ability tooltips for this kind of behavior.

I very much like Swain's W as an ability whose clear, central purpose is to provide vision as a tactical advantage, and I feel this could help define vision across more abilities: if the ability is specifically intended to supply information as utility, then it should likely provide vision or some equivalent, but otherwise it likely shouldn't. With this in mind, I'd personally be okay with Swain's ult not working against invisible enemies, so long as more effects were then retroactively changed to lose their own implicit stealth detection. Once more, we'd be back to a more consistent environment, and ideally one where vision and detection could have a chance to stand out better.

Like, for sure, this is a great reason to not have an ability target stealthed enemies, but when there are abilities like Morgana's ult, Katarina's ult, Kennen's W, etc. to name but a few examples of abilities that do target stealthed champions, having all of these abilities do one thing, and having one ability that does very similar things, with this one exception, isn't really clear to players. Do developers consider consistency when deciding on these mechanics, and if so, how important is consistency to them?

It could definitely benefit from a clarity pass, I think. **Deals damage to the X closest [or all] enemies** vs. **Targets the X closest enemies, doing damage to each** seems like it would help clear up whether the effect ticks through vision/stealth (the former) or requires a visible target (the latter).

For sure, changing the wording could clarify things, particularly if one were to specify whether the ability damaged visible nearby enemies, or all enemies. However, that also kind of dodges the issue, in that it doesn't justify by itself why one ability should do one thing, and another ability that works in a very similar manner should do that thing differently. In this particular case, if it's healthier for Swain's ult to not target invisible opponents, why doesn't this reasoning apply to other auto-targeted abilities? There are effectively two types of inconsistency at work: inconsistency in presentation, in that two very similar abilities can differ in ways the players cannot reasonably expect, but also inconsistency in reasoning, in which those two abilities work differently purely because they stem from two different trains of thought, neither of which were done with consideration for the other. Your proposal solves the first issue, but not the second.

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=roxpMzNU,comment-id=000a000200020000,timestamp=2018-07-12T18:50:50.020+0000)However, that also kind of dodges the issue, in that it doesn't justify by itself why one ability should do one thing, and another ability that works in a very similar manner should do that thing differently.

I guess my suggestion was to help clarify that they aren't intended to work in a similar manner. If one is an "all enemies" effect and one is a "visible targets only" effect that the distinction becomes clearer.

>In this particular case, if it's healthier for Swain's ult to not target invisible opponents, why doesn't this reasoning apply to other auto-targeting abilities?

Because a lot of AoEs don't target -- they're ticking effects. To me this thematically is fairly clear -- effects that set up a "kill zone" don't require visible targets (such as a field of fire), while those that imply action on the part of the champion (throwing knives, sucking souls, etc) do. Now, I also fully understand that you (or others) may disagree on the clarity here, but I think there's definitely room for AoE effects that do require visible targets AND AoE effects that don't, provided the line between them is a bit more clear than it currently is.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=roxpMzNU,comment-id=000a0002000200000000,timestamp=2018-07-12T18:55:01.402+0000)
>
> Because a lot of AoEs don't target -- they're ticking effects. To me this thematically is fairly clear -- effects that set up a "kill zone" don't require visible targets (such as a field of fire), while those that imply action on the part of the champion (throwing knives, sucking souls, etc) do. Now, I also fully understand that you (or others) may disagree on the clarity here, but I think there's definitely room for AoE effects that do require visible targets AND AoE effects that don't, provided the line between them is a bit more clear than it currently is.

Okay, but then we also have a lot of effects that _aren't_ static kill zones: I mentioned this in another post, but we also have stuff like Hecarim's W and Camille's W which impact upon stealthed opponents, and even Morgana's own ult has the same functionality. Whether you like it or not, these abilities have stealth detection, no matter how implicit. For sure, it's _possible_ to do abilities differently, and it could be perfectly valid, but in order to be so there needs to be consistent justification, which should also be clear to players. Here, there does not appear to be any such justification, which is also why many players are pointing out the resulting inconsistency.

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=roxpMzNU,comment-id=000a00020002000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-12T19:13:54.218+0000)Okay, but then we also have a lot of effects that _aren't_ static kill zones: I mentioned this in another post, but we also have stuff like Hecarim's W and Camille's W which impact upon stealthed opponents, and even Morgana's own ult has the same functionality. 

See, to me that isn't a disconnect still -- Morgana's ult specifically grants vision as part of its effect and Hecarim's W is a ticking damage zone, while Camille's is a non-targeted AoE. I guess in my brain any effect that isn't champion-specific in its animation (and Swain's is, as it pulls particles from them to Swain) will logically hit everything regardless of visibility.

Now, there are some weird exceptions to this that I don't like -- namely Katarina, who I don't think respects target visibility, but I must admit I'm not certain.

In short, I think it's a reasonable and intentional chance that only suffers from a lack of clarify because other similar effects (like Katarina's) aren't clear one the distinction, and that it definitely needs a *clarity* pass so that abilities with enemy-specific animations traveling from targets to the champion or from the champion to the targets follow one set of rules while target-agnostic effects that simply apply to everyone in the area follow a second -- but that the mechanical functionality is fine.

With enough digging, anyone could easily come up with some particular argument to justify inconsistencies in functionality such as these; that does not mean doing so justifies anything or addresses the issue at hand.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=roxpMzNU,comment-id=000a00020002000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-12T20:33:23.106+0000)

Sure, but sharing one's thoughts does not automatically contribute to discussion. Everyone has an opinion, and is capable of conjecture, but unless those relate to the context of the discussion and address it, neither will automatically move it forward. "I feel this certain type of way" is certainly an opinion, but provides no opportunity for discussion in and of itself, because ultimately it is just an opinion, untethered by context or fact. By contrast, statements like "several people feel this way", "Riot said X, so this is their official reasoning", or "ability A clearly differs from ability B in this minute component, despite being so similar" are all falsifiable, i.e. verifiable in a manner that cannot be reduced to opinion, and are therefore capable of truly adding to the conversation.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=roxpMzNU,comment-id=000a00020002000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-12T20:33:23.106+0000)

But it's not really a solution though? For sure, improving the wording would help with some portion of the clarity issues, but as mentioned above, that addresses only one of the inconsistencies at hand. Giving out your personal opinion on how you think there's no contradiction between the implementation of certain abilities, doesn't magically solve the problem of many other people still finding those implementations to be inconsistent.

>Sure, but sharing one's thoughts does not automatically contribute to discussion.

Design is all about thoughts though. There's no really objective way to judge "is this ability fun" or "would this character be more fun if we replaced their W, and, if so, what with?" At some level all of these decisions are, ultimately, a bit subjective. What feels right for you may not feel right for me, and vice versa. It doesn't make one of us wrong -- it just means that we don't agree on what the solution to a problem should be in an ideal game state, because we may not agree on the definition of what the ideal game state is.

If you don't personally feel my thoughts are helpful to the discussion you want to have, I encourage you to ignore those thoughts.

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=roxpMzNU,comment-id=000a000200020000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-12T21:22:16.271+0000)...or "ability A clearly differs from ability B in this minute component, despite being so similar" are all falsifiable, i.e. verifiable in a manner that cannot be reduced to opinion, and are therefore capable of truly adding to the conversation.

I think I did do this, but the miscommunication here may stem from the fact that I'm not sure we agree on the issue.

Your issue appears to to be an inconsistency with how area-of-effect effects select targets.

My issue is that I see two distinct types of AoE effects (all targets within the area, and *specific* targets within the area), and I think the clarity between them and the way they are represented needs to be improved.

> But it's not really a solution though?

I mean, I think it is, yes. Drawing better lines regarding the different types of AoE targeting and thinking about how to represent that visually is an equally viable solution to making all AoE effects have similar targeting. Both accomplish the same goal of clarifying "why did I get hit/not get hit," just both do so in different ways.

No matter how good you feel about your opinion, it's not going to achieve anything if it doesn't fit into a larger context, or if it doesn't work with whichever audience you are presenting it to. Note that my issue here is not that I disagree with you; rather, the fact that your justification for presenting your opinion as some general solution is that all of design is subjective, to me indicates that it did not go through this process of context and analysis, and therefore cannot really help with the topic at hand, beyond just giving out one more opinion.
